trainingTypes.title: Our
trainingTypes.description: No training is the same. Learn more about the different building blocks of your personal schedule.

progressionRun.title: Progression Run
progressionRun.subtitle: Start easy, finish strong at race pace.
progressionRun.description: A progression run is a training where you gradually increase the pace during the session. You start at a very comfortable recovery pace and build up until you finish at your target race pace (e.g., 10km or half marathon pace).
benefits: Improves your ability to resist fatigue
Teaches your body to use energy more efficiently
Builds mental confidence for the final phase of a race
Less taxing than a full tempo run
howTo: Start the first 1/3 of the run at your recovery pace (Z1)
Increase in the second 1/3 the pace to your easy long run pace (Z2)
Finish the last 1/3 at your target race pace (Z3/Z4)
Always cool down for 5-10 minutes afterwards
progressionRun.proTip: Focus on a smooth transition. Avoid sudden sprints; the acceleration should be almost imperceptible to an outsider.

ladderWorkout.title: Ladder Workout
ladderWorkout.subtitle: Varying intervals for focus and speed.
ladderWorkout.description: In a ladder interval, you change the duration or distance of each interval. For example: 1 minute, 2 minutes, 3 minutes, and then back to 2 and 1. This challenges both your anaerobic and aerobic system.
benefits: Prevents boredom during hard intervals
Trains different energy systems in one session
Improves your ability to handle pace changes
High calorie burn
howTo: Warm up well for at least 15 minutes
Follow the "rungs" of the ladder precisely
Take the prescribed rest between each rung (usually jogging)
Keep the pace on the short rungs slightly higher than on the long rungs
ladderWorkout.proTip: The way "down" (e.g., from 3 to 2 to 1 minute) is where the real gain is. Try to maintain your technique well here despite the fatigue.

tempoRun.title: Tempo Run
tempoRun.subtitle: Raise your anaerobic threshold with constant speed.
tempoRun.description: A Tempo Run is performed at your anaerobic threshold. This is the pace you can maintain for about an hour. The goal is to train your body to run faster without lactate accumulating.
benefits: Increases your speed over longer distances
Improves your running economy
Strengthens your mental focus at constant high effort
Trains your body to clear lactate faster
howTo: Start with a 10-15 minute warm-up
Run 20-40 minutes at your threshold pace (Z4)
The effort should feel like a 7 or 8 on a scale of 10
End with a 10 minute cool-down
tempoRun.proTip: If you feel like you need to sprint to maintain the pace, you're going too fast. A tempo run should be hard, but controlled.

aerobicThreshold.title: Aerobic Threshold (AeT)
aerobicThreshold.subtitle: The foundation of your endurance.
aerobicThreshold.description: The aerobic threshold is the highest pace at which you still train fully aerobically (without significant lactate buildup). This pace feels "comfortably challenging". For marathon runners, this is the most important training type.
benefits: Significantly increases your aerobic capacity
Teaches your body to burn fats more efficiently as fuel
Lowers your heart rate at a given pace in the long term
Shorter recovery time than anaerobic training
howTo: This pace is usually between Z2 and Z3
Maintain a pace where you can still speak short sentences, but no longer have full conversations
Focus on a constant heart rate
Sessions often last between 45 and 90 minutes
aerobicThreshold.proTip: Use a heart rate monitor to prevent you from inadvertently going above your threshold. Less is more in this zone.

fartlek.title: Fartlek
fartlek.subtitle: Playing with speed in an unstructured way.
fartlek.description: Fartlek is Swedish for "speed play". Unlike structured intervals, in fartlek you change your pace based on your environment or feeling.
benefits: Makes training more fun and less monotonous
Trains both your aerobic and anaerobic system
Teaches you to listen to your body instead of the GPS
Ideal for trail runners and cross country runners
howTo: Run your normal long run route
Choose an object (e.g., a tree or lamppost) and sprint to it
Recover at a slow jog until you have your breath back
Repeat this as often as you like
fartlek.proTip: Use fartlek in weeks when you feel mentally tired. The freedom of speed play often works refreshingly.

steadyState.title: Steady State Run
steadyState.subtitle: Slightly faster than long run, focus on rhythm.
steadyState.description: A Steady State run is a longer run at a constant pace that is slightly faster than your normal long run, but slower than a tempo run. It is the "sweet spot" for aerobic development.
benefits: Improves your endurance at race pace
Builds physical and mental strength
Trains muscle fibers for long distances
Less tiring than a tempo run but more effective than Z2
howTo: Determine your target pace (often marathon or half marathon pace)
Maintain this pace constantly for 45 to 90 minutes
Focus on stable breathing and good technique
Warm up for 10 minutes and cool down for 10 minutes
steadyState.proTip: Try to do this run on a flat course to keep your pace perfectly constant.

yasso800s.title: Yasso 800s
yasso800s.subtitle: The ultimate predictor for your marathon time.
yasso800s.description: A famous workout where you run 10x 800 meters. The theory is that the time you do over 800m (in minutes and seconds) predicts your marathon time in hours and minutes.
benefits: Very accurate indication of your marathon fitness
Builds enormous speed and endurance
Provides a heavy physical stimulus in your peak weeks
Easy to measure progress
howTo: Warm up very well for 20 minutes
Run 800m at your target time (e.g., 3:30 for a 3:30 marathon)
Take as much rest as you ran (jogging)
Repeat until you reach 10 repetitions
yasso800s.proTip: Don't start your schedule with 10 repetitions. Start with 4 or 5 and build up to 10 every two weeks.

hillRepeats.title: Hill Training
hillRepeats.subtitle: Build explosive power and improve your technique.
hillRepeats.description: Hill sprints are one of the most effective ways to build running strength. By working against gravity, you force your muscles to maximum effort.
benefits: Improves your push-off and running efficiency
Strengthens tendons and ligaments (fewer injuries)
Trains your heart to recover faster
Trains the correct knee drive and arm movement
howTo: Find a hill with a 4-6% gradient
Sprint 30-60 seconds uphill with focus on technique
Walk or jog very slowly back down as recovery
Repeat 6 to 12 times
hillRepeats.proTip: Don't look at your feet, but keep your gaze about 15 meters ahead. Stay upright and don't let your hips drop.

baseRun.title: Base Run
baseRun.subtitle: Simple long runs for a strong aerobic base.
baseRun.description: The Base Run is a short to medium long run at your natural, comfortable pace. It's not a recovery run, but also not a heavy effort. The goal is building volume.
benefits: Improves your general aerobic fitness
Strengthens the heart and lungs
Prepares your tendons for heavier training
Increases capillary density in your muscles
howTo: Run at a pace where you can easily talk (Z2)
Focus on a relaxed posture
Keep the pace constant, even on slight inclines
These runs make up 60-70% of your weekly volume
baseRun.proTip: Many runners do their Base Runs too fast. If you're exhausted afterwards, it wasn't a Base Run.

mafLowHeartRate.title: MAF (low heart rate)
mafLowHeartRate.subtitle: Build your base with easy, sustainable training.
mafLowHeartRate.description: MAF stands for "Maximum Aerobic Function". You train mainly at a low heart rate (aerobic zone) to improve endurance and reduce injury risk. The pace can feel surprisingly easy at first, but consistency is where the long-term gains come from.
benefits: Stronger aerobic base without overload
Improved fat oxidation and energy efficiency
Lower injury risk due to low intensity
Great for rebuilding fitness steadily
howTo: Estimate your MAF heart rate (rough guideline: 180 - age, with adjustments)
Keep most easy runs at or below that heart rate
Add 1-2 extra easy sessions instead of intensity
Re-test every 3-4 weeks: same HR ‚Üí faster pace = progress
mafLowHeartRate.proTip: Use a heart-rate monitor and accept that the pace starts slow. It typically improves after a few consistent weeks.

polarized8020.title: 80/20 (Polarized)
polarized8020.subtitle: 80% easy, 20% hard: a smart balance for progress.
polarized8020.description: The 80/20 (polarized) approach divides training into lots of easy running and a smaller dose of high intensity. By keeping easy days truly easy, you can execute the quality sessions better and recover faster.
benefits: Better progress with less fatigue
Higher quality in tempo/interval sessions
Clear structure: easy days easy, hard days hard
Works well from 5K to marathon
howTo: Keep ~80% of total running time easy (you should be able to talk)
Schedule 1-2 hard sessions per week depending on experience
Add a long run when training for 10 miles, half marathon or marathon
Audit your easy pace: many runners run 'easy' too fast
polarized8020.proTip: When in doubt, slow down on easy days. It‚Äôs usually the fastest way to get fitter.

runWalkGalloway.title: Run-Walk (Galloway)
runWalkGalloway.subtitle: Planned walk breaks for control and durability.
runWalkGalloway.description: The Run-Walk method (Galloway) combines running with planned walk breaks, for example 3 minutes run / 1 minute walk. It keeps load manageable, helps recovery, and makes longer distances achievable‚Äîespecially when (re)starting or building toward long goals.
benefits: Lower impact on tendons and joints
More even pacing and fewer late-race blow-ups
Great for rebuilding or fatigue-sensitive runners
Effective for long runs and marathon goals
howTo: Pick a simple ratio (e.g., 3:1 or 4:1) and stick to it
Start conservative: easier is better than too hard
Use Run-Walk for long runs and high-stress weeks
Progress gradually: longer run blocks, shorter walk breaks, or longer total time
runWalkGalloway.proTip: Walk before you‚Äôre tired. The magic is in proactive pacing, not reacting to fatigue.

jackDanielsPaceZones.title: Jack Daniels (pace zones)
jackDanielsPaceZones.subtitle: Train with precise pace zones based on your current fitness.
jackDanielsPaceZones.description: Jack Daniels‚Äô method uses training zones (E, M, T, I, R) derived from your current performance. That makes training highly specific: easy when it should be easy, and targeted when it needs to be hard.
benefits: Highly specific training with clear paces
Great for PR-oriented goals
Solid balance between volume and quality
Helps prevent going too hard by using concrete zones
howTo: Determine your zones from a recent race or test (VDOT-style)
Plan 1 quality session (T/I/R) and 1 long run (E/M) per week
Keep easy runs truly easy (E) for recovery
Update zones after clear progress (e.g., every 4-6 weeks)
jackDanielsPaceZones.proTip: On good days the paces can feel 'too easy'. Stick to the zone‚Äîconsistency beats spikes.

lydiardPeriodized.title: Lydiard (periodized)
lydiardPeriodized.subtitle: Periodization: base ‚Üí strength ‚Üí speed ‚Üí taper.
lydiardPeriodized.description: Lydiard uses distinct phases. You first build a strong aerobic base (lots of easy volume), then add hills/strength, and only later focus on hard speed work. This suits runners who want to peak in a structured, long-term way.
benefits: Strong base before intensity increases
Logical periodization toward peak weeks
Lower overload risk thanks to phased build-up
Well suited for medium and long distances
howTo: Phase 1: aerobic base (lots of easy volume + long run)
Phase 2: hills/strength (hill sessions, strides, technique)
Phase 3: speed/tempo (intervals and threshold work)
Phase 4: taper (reduce volume, keep sharpness)
lydiardPeriodized.proTip: Don‚Äôt skip the base phase. If it‚Äôs too short, you‚Äôll feel it in the hard weeks later.

hansonsMethod.title: Hansons
hansonsMethod.subtitle: Consistent volume with a relatively shorter long run.
hansonsMethod.description: Hansons is a marathon (and half marathon) approach built around consistency: several medium-long runs during the week plus a long run that‚Äôs often shorter than in traditional plans. The idea is to train the long run with accumulated fatigue, closer to race conditions.
benefits: Strong race-specific fitness through consistent volume
Less extreme long runs than classic marathon plans
Clear structure with repeatable weeks
Fits runners training 4-6 days per week
howTo: Schedule multiple medium-long runs during the week
Add 1 tempo/threshold session and 1 speed/interval session
Keep recovery runs truly easy
Protect recovery: sleep and easy days are non-negotiable
hansonsMethod.proTip: Hansons often feels like you‚Äôre 'a bit tired'. That‚Äôs normal‚Äîbut if pains start, reduce intensity first.

pfitzingerMethod.title: Pfitzinger
pfitzingerMethod.subtitle: Higher volume and quality for experienced marathoners.
pfitzingerMethod.description: Pfitzinger (P&D) is an intensive approach with higher weekly volume, long runs, and demanding midweek medium-long runs. It‚Äôs designed for experienced runners who can handle many training days and want to peak for a marathon.
benefits: Major aerobic gains through volume
Race-specific stimulus via long runs and medium-long runs
Clear progression toward peak weeks
Great for performance-oriented marathon goals
howTo: Make sure you can handle 5+ training days before starting
Plan 1 long run, 1 medium-long run, and 1 quality session per week
Use easy days actively as recovery (E pace)
Take cutback weeks seriously to prevent overtraining
pfitzingerMethod.proTip: This isn‚Äôt a plan to 'try out'. If recovery isn‚Äôt solid, choose a more sustainable method.
